title: Will Roger Goodell be commissioner of the NFL at the start of the 2016 regular season?

The Washington Post just published an article that reflects quite positively on the Commish.  He might be disposed to staying on a few years and being part of a search committee. Yes, he is hated nearly equally by everyone. Equality is perceived as fairness; fairness is one of the most important qualities in NFL Commissioner, along with financial prosperity. Teams continue to increase rapidly in value. Therefore, Goodell will likely remain. He could, however, be involved in an accident, injury, or decide to retire. Retirement would likely carry too high an opportunity cost for him.

He didn't get fired yet, and there are plenty of reasons he should have been.  The league owners are going to stick with the known quantity, rather than hoping the next commissioner will follow the protocols they want.

According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Goodell will continue to be the NFL commissioner unless he has health problems that prevent him.

Goodell has weathered worse storms than the current one, not that these high-profile issues matter much anyway. NFL revenues continue to rise and Goodell reports to the league owners, which should be all it takes for him to remain on.
I had this at 99% - upping it to 100% (i.e. greater than a 99.5% chance) as the deadline's closer.

According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Goodell will continue to be the NFL commissioner unless he has health problems that prevent him.

Roger's role continues to be augmented to limit his involvement in punishment decisions so that he can focus on league growth, something he has been particularly adept at in recent years. This statistical fact (NFL growth) in conjunction with decisions to streamline his role suggest that a commissioner change is not imminent.
The closer we get to the start of the season the less time there is for something to happen.

Given that we are currently in late June and the season starts in September, the chances a commissioner is unexpectedly removed within a two month stretch is very low. Further, the people who need to remove him from his current position are making the most money they ever have as NFL owners.

Base rate is high - NFL commissioners tend to see out their contracts

Deflategate is far less important overall than either domestic violence from NFL players or concussions.  Goodell has survived both.  While it is possible that this is the "hay that breaks the Goodell back", it seems unlikely unless it can be tied to something more systematic and/or intentional.

His job's to make money for the owners, and to take all the flak. Both seem to be going well, and he's extremely well paid, so I don't think he's going anywhere. The fact that he's a clueless hypocritical f**kpig is neither here nor there.

There have been no current calls for his resignation since 2014 when NOW wanted him to step down.  This far into 2016 there would have to be something unforeseen happen for him not to be commissioner come this Fall.

The NFL is expected to make over 13 billion dollars this year (2016) in total revenue, and this upward trend has been consistent since he arrived in 2006. Also, there have been 8 NFL Commissioners in league history and only 1 has been ousted from office as a result of incompetence. Base rate information and financial success of the league all point to Goodell still being commissioner for the next NFL season.

Under his watch NFL owners, his employers, have made a lot of money, so they aren't naturally inclined to want him out from a business perspective. He is also being paid very well having made between 34 and 44 million dollars per year the last several years, so I don't see him as being inclined to give up the job, particularly since he has fought through calls for his resignation over several scandals the past few years. Could there be a scandal that he would be unable to survive, sure. But he has so far survived so I put it at a pretty small chance.

In this case the dictator is being propped up by his subjects. Why would he leave?
Commissioners hold their job for a long time -- much many years longer than this tenure --  The first game is 8 September which is 138 days away -- not that far.
He's doing what the owners want him to do.  Despite any controversy, he's doing what his employers expect of him.
Goodell will continue to be the NFL commissioner unless he has health problems that prevent him.
He hasn't done that bad of a job, NFL still makes lots of money, why would the owners want to take a chance on someone else.
No news that Goodell plans to resign as the NFL commissioner in the near future, but anything can happen at anytime.
No news that Goodell plans to resign as the NFL commissioner in the near future, but anything can happen at anytime.

There are several factors which could erode Goodell's ability to retain his post but the largest risk factor is the NFL's correlation to CTE.  For now the issue is contained but as more data is revealed it will impact the public's perception of Goodell.  If information surfaces of a "cover-up" particularly one in which Goodell is personally involved then he could lose his job.   However, the season starts in less than 6 months so the likelihood of Goodell losing his job is low given the lack of connection between Goodell and CTE knowledge.

The turnover for commissioners is real low.  He'll be here for a while, unless he does something really horrible. That said, look at his cold, dead eyes.  Solid 2% chance one of the skeletons falls out of his closet.

Deflategate has given Goodell widespread criticism; however, the terms of his current contract as commissioner along with his ability to generate increasing amounts of revenue for the NFL will help him keep his job.
average length of a previous commissioner's term >15 yrs. Revenue matches or exceeds projections year over year
No news that Goodell plans to resign as the NFL commissioner in the near future.
sentiment on the web about Roger is generally  positive. He seems to be keeping a lid on the concussion debacle, so the owners will continue to love him. He'll continue.

Sadly.  The league continues to lose credibility and integrity with their statements and actions on concussions and CTE as well as "deflategate" yet the owners seem to value growing revenue and expanding internationally with Roger as point.

He's survived this long with no major outcry so it seems likely we will be there.  However, I think the head trauma issues are starting to gain some traction.  If the issue continues to gain traction, I could see him stepping down.

There's a lot of controversy surrounding the commissioner, but a lot of this comes from controversy around the nfl in general. I think the owners want to keep him in his same position. There is a small chance that the concussion issues or the deflategate thing comes back to bite him.
I don't know. Just my feeling that he will not.
No news that Goodell plans to resign as the NFL commissioner.
Not enough pressure to move him on his way out right now. The owners would have to gather en mass for this to happen.
Kraft is the most likely owner to start the ball rolling for a new Commissioner, and he is smart enough to move deliberately.

Goodell's contract is set to run through March 2019. The NFL has continued to be the United State's most popular sport under Goodell and he continues to receive strong support from various NFL owners. Though Goodell's tenure hasn't been perfect by any means (lock out, Ray Rice incident, Deflate-gate), it would take a $150 million buyout to shoo Goodell away from the league. That being said, a relatively quiet 2016 summer should virtually guarantee his job at the beginning of the 2016 season.

Goodell under contract thru 2018, NFL has strong revenue growth trend, salary cap controlling largest cost element, concussion risk mitigated with 2015 settlement are all factors that say stay the course.  Deflategate was a big screwup for Goodell as outside analysis showed intentional deflating was highly unlikely but Goodell seemed able to shrug it off and it's now old news.  He's on a good ride and very unlikely to step down for something else.
I don't see reason to believe at this stage that Commissioner Goodell would be on his way out.

Looked into the history of commissioners, the last 6 or 7, and among those there were several that were interim situations where they were only commissioner for a short while due to some internal wrangling etc. In the grand scheme of commissioners, the length of time he's been in the job is already on the long side and approaching the very long side for commissioners--although there have been Facebook hate pages about him since he started, and various articles denouncing him, as well as the recent bunch of player safety and player punishment issues that have made him look bad publicly, I think the NFL, internally, likes him. His skyrocketing salary, up to a few years ago can be viewed online-by some legal technicality, it won't be publicly disclosed in the future, but what this demonstrates is that he is hitting his internal NFL benchmarks or metrics; he is accomplishing whatever he's promised internally, or at least is maintaining positive perceptions inside with at least enough of the key decision makers to stick around and keep getting huge pay increases.
Bumping down a bit on rumors that he might resign due to taking away his disciplinary powers.
they have discussed reducing his role, specifically in the arbitration department.

Looking at what the chances goodell would be replaced I would first say average tenure of nfl commissioner in past 70 years is at least >10 years, with the last one at 17 years and three ago at 29 years so I would say that there's a 33% chance that he would be replaced next year, however, there has been a lot of controversy over this past year's debacles so some public opinion would put it at 43%, however, the last time a commissioner resigned was in 1946 so I would put that back down to 23%. Lastly, there have been recent articles talking about a potential move to change his ability to discipline players, but not remove him as commissioner and I would imagine that compromise is a more likely scenario, if it happens at all, so I think the probability that he isn't commissioner is more like 13%. Beyond this, if they were going to continue to try to oust him as commissioner, they would be trying for that deal instead of trying to change his powers, so I would lower it even more to about 8%. This would mean my forecast that he is commissioner is 92%, and minus 1% in case he dies, so I would put it at 91%.
Moving back up.  It looks like we caught an internet "rumor" live, that's being debunked as we speak.

Most of the news media is addressing changes to Goodell's ability to discipline players. I was earlier at 98-99 with no news suggesting any problems. If there is a discussion of limiting his power, that was too high. If parties are at odds enough to suggest changing his role, a 3-4% chance of removal seems plausible if negotiations fail. And, a 1% chance he dies of natural causes, or random causes force him to lose his position.
Just moderating a bit on @Ermonic's post.  I don't believe they're trying to push Goodell out, but it shows that secret deals are being made all the time.
He's the owners' mouth piece. They'd have to quietly find candidates and then train a new guy to do it the way they want, all over again.
Although there have been testing moments goodell has been able to weather the storm

The Commissioner is hired and retained by the owners.  The owners run the NFL as a sport and will respond to issues like player behavior and head trauma with a view to preserving and expanding the bottom line.  They will change the Commissioner when he starts to cost them money and he has not done that yet.
I see no reason as to why he wouldn't. If he started last season with all the fuzz about Deflategate, He will start this season.

League is mainly focused on revenues and he has done a good job of growing them. Football will eventually be disrupted by something else, probably soccer. But that will take a few more years and till then, Goodell is fine.
The owners are afraid to speak out against him, unfortunately
The "Deflategate" scandal has all but passed.

The NFL owners are a club.  Roger Goodell has several owners on his corner. He has to name an operations person re-structure the organization and to take the blame for some of the operations miscalculations while Goodell takes the glory. Today there is no buffer between a scandal and Goodell. This is an organization nightmare for a CEO.

When he  showed up late to his press conference and unprepared.  These missteps added to the meltdown of the NFL image. 
I think that time will tell if the new measures unveiled by Goodell have worked. Meanwhile he has the ear of his owners and he seem to have recuperated from this meltdown.
It's all about the money and he has benefited the owners immensely.
There are no upcoming scandals to harm his position and he's in fairly good health and should be alive.

The league continues to make money hand over fist. The scandals seem not to have made a serious dent. I don't see the owners being motivated to make a change, especially during the transition involving the NFL in Los Angeles.
he shouldnt be, but he's doing a great job of being a scapegoat for the less than scrupulous owners of the league.

I believe that the owners likely have Goodell on a short leash, but a sudden change in leadership would do more to harm the value of their investments than maintaining the leadership of Goodell at least until a replacement could be readied to take over. It is also worth noting that the popularity of the NFL was not materially impacted by scandals

As long as the public stories of CTE stay below the national evening news reporting, soccor moms will let their sons and daughter play, keeping youth leagues in business, feeding talent into high school jv & varsity athletics; feeding into college sports, etc. Will the death of "The Juice" reveal he suffered from brain trauma, partially explaining his violence to his wife and her violent death?. Watch the supermarket check out tabloids for CTE related stories. If they pop, Godell could be let go.
Yes he was groomed for the position
Goodell has the backing of far too many NFL owners to lose his job. He has come through the worst of it with little apparent damage within the owner ranks.
Owners want a transition that would be smooth and non controversial. That means having an heir fully groomed and ready. Still too much speculation around possible candidates.

There is a history of long running NFL commissioners dating back to 1960 (Goodell is the third NFL commissioner since 1960 according to Wikipedia). This not a position that has changed personnel with much regularity for the previous 50 years and so is not a "hot seat job."
Not changing forecast, but this is an interesting read:

The only shot that Goodell has to be fired would be in another major scandal. The NFL is prone to scandals and in the past, Goodell has had Robert Kraft's support, which is looking unlikely to have. However, this season went by without any major hitches and overall public support seems strong. Eventually, Goodell might lose his position but that day is almost certainly not this next season

Based on information gathered, it seems highly likely that Goodell will be brought back as commissioner for the 2016 regular season. To answer this question, I broke it down into more specific ones—S in CHAMPS KNOW (select the right questions to answer and forecasts to make). Since the owners decide on his employment status, I asked two specific questions relevant to them: has Goodell made money for the owners, and have any new scandals arisen in the recent playoffs or thereafter? On the first question, as commissioner Goodell has brought in billions for the league through massive TV contracts and successful promotion of the NFL. Success in this respect is perhaps most important to owners, as the league is a business for them. On the second question, the NFL seems to have had a good season avoiding scandals, and since the Super Bowl, no new information about potential NFL-wide scandals has arisen that would lead to Goodell’s firing. With both of these questions answered confidently (based on available information), there seems to be a 97% chance Goodell will be brought back in 2016. Nevertheless, W from CHAMPS KNOW (wildcards, accidents, and black swans can catch you if you don’t consider the risk of irreducible uncertainty) encouraged me to be more careful in my judgment. Because of the nature of scandals to come out of no where, and the natural possibility that natural causes hinder Goodell’s ability to be commissioner, I adjust downward to 92%--representing caution for unexpected events that would lead to his firing.

C Though Goodell’s contract is set to run through march of 2019, it is important to note some of the differences between him and the previous commissioner, Paul Tagliabue. Tagliabue is widely believed to be one of the best NFL commissioners the league has seen. During his tenure, there was never a single player lockout or strike, and he took the league to new heights through his strategic TV deals and publicity campaigns. Goodell, however, has had a much more controversial history as commissioner and is not heavily favored by many of his peers in addition to NFL players and fans. 
H There has yet to be a commissioner in history that has had his contract terminated, and that fact will most likely not change with Goodell. His secure contract along with extensive support from various NFL owners will help keep his job safe. 
A There has been no news or headlines to change the last forecast regarding Goodell’s job security, and it appears to be a near certainty that he will be commissioner next season. In addition, the 2016 season is officially over, and there will be little activity within the NFL until the next season, so Goodell will have little involvement and thus little room to make any controversial decisions. 
M Considering recent polls and surveys regarding Goodell, it is clearly that he is not extensively “liked” within the greater football community, however no models or statistics have shown that his tenure as NFL commissioner is anywhere near over in the years to come. 
P It becomes difficult to make a post-mortem analyses given the fact that the 2016 season has not started, however recent data indicates that he will indeed be the commissioner for the upcoming season. 
S Questions to consider are: How will Goodell respond to ongoing lawsuits with head trauma from former players? How will he respond in the future in terms of league policies and player misconduct? These are driving questions that pertain to how Goodell will be perceived by the public. 
K The key players that may influence Goodell’s job security are himself, the players, and NFL owners. 
N Goodell can consider his job security safe unless he is found to violate the integrity of the NFL, which is the only grounds on which he can be voted out of the NFL. Such integrity came into question with the Ray Rice scandal, however since then a similar event has not resurfaced. 
O Another perspective to take into account is that of NFL owners. Take for example, Robert Kraft of the Patriots. The two have been accused of having mutually beneficial relationships in which Goodell lets Kraft cheat while Kraft ensures that Goodell keeps his job amid all of the controversy. 
W A potential wildcard could be a player misconduct issue that arises before the 2016 season that Goodell handles extremely poorly. Only such a scenario may lead to his contract termination for the upcoming season.

To change this prediction, I am using the "Adjust and update your forecasts when appropriate" method of CHAMPSKNOW. While I still think that there is a very high likelihood (almost definite) of Goodell returning as commissioner for the 2016 season, there are 2 factors that are causing me to lower slightly from 99-95.
Goodell weathered the storm of last off season and made $34 million last year.  He has the support of the owners, who ultimately decide his fate.
Barring tiny chance of physical illness, scandal, retirement or other unforseen event. This is all but certain
Until further notice going with consensus.

(1) There would have to be another scandal of enormous magnitude and Roger Goodell would have to be implicated as being involved; (2) Or Goodell would have to suffer a serious health issue, and he appears to be in relatively good shape. Took 1% off for each possibility.
The main factors of him not being commissioner would be death, health or extreme bad judgement that would alienate the majority of owners.
He's only out if he upsets the majority of owners. He's never come close to doing that.
Only health reasons would prevent such an outcome

Lazy prediction - but looking at consensus, press, and issues Goodell has faced, I see minimal risk of him not continuing another year as commissioner. His bumper salary suggests he is doing an excellent job, with the board unlikely to not have his backing after such a payment. Cumulative risks of personal issues, ill health, public scrutiny over salary, or another big scandle prevent this from being a clean 100%, but his tenure and performance to date make this highly unlikely to result in any other outcome

Roger Goodell will almost definitely be the commissioner of the NFL next year. Some of the reasons include 1.) Despite owner Robert Craft of the New England patriots calling Goodell out and scrutinizing his decision to uphold Tom Brady's suspension and their forfeiture of draft picks, Goodell has the backing of a majority of the owners in the league, and many of the most powerful as well such as Jerry Jones, Jeffrie Lurie and the Rams owner Stan Kroenke, who is among the richest owners in the league and is moving his franchise to LA next year. It is also important to note that Goodell took a backseat in the debate over which franchise would move to LA next year. It was a heated debate and Goodell chose to take a backseat to ensure that he wouldnt waste any of his political capital (which he has lost alot of in recent years) by choosing one side over another. However, there are some other factors which need to be considered that could change this forecast if they occurred. Some factors that could alter this prediction and give Goodell less of a chance to be commissioner next year would be 1) how he handles the Johnny Manziel discipline situation. 2) How his appeal of Tom Brady's deflategate case decision plays out 3) if any other major discipline issues arise which he handles in a way that is not met favorable by the public. However, I believe that the chances of these potential factors playing much of a role in if he is commissioner next year are very small and will not make much of a difference. Historically, there has been six commissioners in NFL history and they average reign has been about 13 years, and amny of the shorter terms came in the early days of the league, skewing this data's average to be a little smaller than we would expect. As a result, I would expect Roger Godell to have a 99% chance of being the commissioner next year, mostly due to the fact that he has the backing by a majority of the most powerful owners.

There has been little sign that there is an issue with Roger Goodell being the commissioner of the NFL.  Most of the criticism came from the "deflate gate" handling but this was 2 years back.  This year he handled some controversial plays (hits) fairly well and I think he is almost certainly going to be the commissioner of the NFL for the next season (and as a result at the beginning of the  2016 regular season).
One successful Super Bowl later, with Deflategate a distant memory and Peyton Manning a hero, Goodell's chances look even better.
I am so tired of the NFL.  this is more fun and less predictable.
Not as long as he stays on track to build NFL revenues and continues to do what the majority of key owners wants.
He could die.  The HGH Peyton Manning thing might be handled poorly enough to have him bounced. He could be involved in some sort of scandal.

While public opinion is against him, Goodell works for the team owners. Given that the NFL is extremely profitable at the moment, and has growth prospects as a result of having teams moving to LA, I don't think that they would pressure him to leave. Barring any new information on deflategate, or other scandals, I don't think that public pressure would increase during the offseason.
Seems to have gotten past deflate-gate a long time ago.

NFL is raking in money like crazy, and the owners see Goodell as a good steward for their violent, body-wrecking, gladiatorial game. It's going to take a lot more than Deflategate or a few concussion-related suicides to show Goodell the door.

A new commissioner is chosen after a little less than one year in ten. Goodell is unlikely to retire, which should bump the odds up, but he's also currently overseeing a period when the NFL's image is on the downslope, which might make him or other league executives look bad to the ownership and raise the odds of replacement.

1) No NFL commissioner has ever been fired from their position from what I can see, so prior probability of him getting fired is 0
2) resignation is a possibility, but Goodell appears to have weathered scandals before without incident and most seem to have died down
3) his contract extends through 2019, and though I am unable to find the exact contract contracts of that sort tend to have fairly heavy termination or severance packages
4) There is a non-zero chance of resignation considering how mired in scandal he is, but not enough to bring down such a large prior probability

Goodell's current contract extends through 2019. The NFL is a continuously growing entity and with the controversy of "deflategate" having significantly died down, there is no reason to believe that anything drastic should happen to Goodell by the start of the 2016 season.

If it ain't broke...then why fix it.  The NFL is drowning in $$$$.  Cannot imagine the owners want to risk anything that might upset this.  Not a bad gig either, I think I read somewhere that earns something like $30 million annually.
Deflategate is old news.  Solid growth in NFL over his tenure will solidify his power structure.  This is even despite botching payer discipline issues.  Only way he isn't there is if he retires.
Last few commissioners served for ~20 years, so chance of stepping down in an offseason is 5% at most and Goodell isn't facing any particular challenges.

Have heard no rumors to the contrary from within the NFL, just fans, but the commissioner's job is to do just that: take the form of an evil businessmen trying to ruin the game that the players and coaches work so hard to play well. Makes for a good story when Brady and the Patriots are put up against Goodell, which is exactly the owners want.

If NFL owners want to  make a change, it will be the annual league meeting in March, or Spring meetings in May. No buzz for this happening. Even NE owner, who should have a beef with the comish, is playing nice. If there is a movement afoot, it's very very stealth. Or more likely non-existent. The only voters that matter, 31 owners, are pretty happy with the state of the game(~$500million for Rams relocation! Floating in money).
$44M contract is hard to walk away from.   Will want to see how the LA Rams transition goes.  2 more years.
His job is to make the owners money. He does that. He works for them and they're happy.
Brady isn't in the Super Bowl
NFL commissioners have history of long tenure.  League is more profitable than ever.  The NFL does not like to admit mistakes.  If they fire Goodall they would be admitting to one.
No news is good new for Goodell to keep his job.

3/4 vote would be required to oust him out.
Current contract goes to 2017-2018 season.
At 56 probability of dying is low even though his father died at age 61 and his mom at age 54. 
He could decide to leave on his own account

I'll shoot slightly lower than the consensus, just simply because Goodell doesn't need the money and could walk away into retirement on some private island in the Caribbean at any time if he decides the petulant whining of the owners, the players, and the media isn't worth it. And, frankly, I'm not sure I'd blame him.
Unless a drastic revelation comes regarding 'Deflate gate', he will remain Commissioner.
He has the backing of the rest of the league and the majority of the owners
In his own words he's said nothing would cause him to be fired or resign.  He continues to win on the bottom line.  In the NFL, that's all that matters.  He's got full support of the owners.

Goodell will most likely remain commissioner.  Ray Rice, Deflategate and concussion controversy may make him an expedient political liability , particularly if one of these stories reignites over the course of the year.
Barring a catastrophic expose on CTE and direct suppression by Goodell
He is close to key owners and has weathered scandals which would have derailed most others. Obviously he has "a big hook".

The owners absolutely love Roger Goodell - and they are the ones paying his salary.  He'll be fine despite the controversy over "Deflategate" and the focus on concussions.  The only way he'll ever be in trouble is if football somehow stops making gobs of money - which is unlikely in the near-term.
Boosting to account for the flow of time.

Frankly, apart from occasional references to "Deflategate" last year on 538, I have no knowledge of NFL politics. However, in the spirit of "Just for Fun" I'm joining the challenge, relying on the consensus.

Low health risk for hospitalization, etc. based on age (56) - but that's still what's holding me at 97%. Contract extension through 2018. Controversies about ethics, conduct, player health risk are not what have driven out commissioners in the past. Risky issues are settled - 2016 decisions to move teams, TV contracts in place 2014-2022, CBA runs through 2021.

Goodell will be ousted if 1) The LA deal completely turns into a shit storm, 2) he retires himself because let's be honest, there is a high probability that some NFL players will get into some type of mischief this upcoming offseason, and 3) the Peyton Manning growth hormone accusations goes really south, and I don't see Goodell wanting to deal with an NFL Legend and PEDs.
He works for the owners, not the fans.  He is making money for them.  They will not fire him except for some truly egregious scandal.  Given past events, the owners egregious threshold is quite high.

The ONLY way I see Goodell out of his position as commissioner is through voluntary resignation due to an unforeseen circumstance (family, legal, personal health.) Otherwise, although the media has targeted his mistakes as critical, they do not deem him unfit for his position.
Deflategate: it's baaaack! Or not. I'll keep track for awhile to see whether the latest might become much ado about nothing.
Rams moving to LA. Big money for owners. That's what it's all about.
Upping my forecast to 100. No way Goodell is out by 2016. All major controversies (deflategate, concussions & injuries) appear to have resolved sufficiently for him to keep his job.

Changing to higher possibility-He has a lot of power and has been there a long time. He has the support of most of the owners, but he's had to deal with a lot of mini scandals with the players in the past couple of years, so there is a chance that if something else surfaced that gave the NFL a "black eye" he could either resign or be removed.

He has a lot of power and has been there a long time. He has the support of most of the owners, but he's had to deal with a lot of mini scandals with the players in the past couple of years, so there is a chance that if something else surfaced that gave the NFL a "black eye" he could either resign or be removed.
Giving owners wide berth on the effort to get back into LA market and the Rams move back, initally to the Coliseum, is enough of a reason to go all in on this which is larger than "deflategate."
The LA deal is going to make a lot of money for the owners and unless there is a major scandal, the owners should be content with Goodell's performance.

While Goddell has ruled with an iron fist, under his tenure as commissioner, the NFL has witnessed a tremendous rise in popularity. I do not find him likely to remain commissioner beyond his contract, but that does not expire until 2019.
Now Trump's attacking the NFL, everything is all good!
The owners love Goodell. He gave Rams the green light to move, now all the owners agree, too.
as long as the league is making money hand over fist the owners have no reason to replace him
He's keeping the owners happy, and fans variously riled up or rejoicing. The owners' commissioner: I think they'll keep him.
He's weathered the scandals so far. Destroying evidence in "Spygate" didn't cost him his job. He's made himself indispensable to the right people.

Here ESPN does a longform expose on Goodell. Nothing new, at least to NFL followers. But smart stuff. It confirms to me he's incompetent, but I don't count. Full disclosure, I'm not an NFL team owner.  The owners I think are still happy with him as an earner and have him under a very big contract until 2018. http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/13533995/split-nfl-new-england-patriots-apart

Past handling of cases regarding player behavior, especially those that had an impact on the perception of female fans, was not enough for ownership to make a change.  So barring any personal circumstances that would otherwise prevent him, he'll remain in the job.

He has a contract until 2018. Details aren't known, but it's probably for lots of money. He'll have to start losing money for the league before a likely expensive buyout is taken.  He's making the owners money, and that is the bottom line for the only people who matter to his employment. http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/7502396/commissioner-roger-goodell-gets-extension-2018-season
Too much shit flying in the NFL right now, for continuity he'll hang.
Confirming prior forecast. They won't try to fix what isn't obviously broken.
The NFL rarely changes commissioners -- even if this commissioner is incredibly incompetent, the resistance to change is strong.
He's an awful commissioner but the NFL is making a lot of money.  For a majority of the owners (most who run teams that suck) Goodell is as good as it gets.
Darn tootin', he ain't ridin' into no sunset no time soon.
No news about Goodell is better news than good news because his job is to stay in the background. Reaffirming prior prediction.
With Bob Krafts blessing Goodell will continue as commissioner.
Just because I believe he will for all the reasons stated below and that the median was 5 points more than my prediction.  ;)

Follow the money... the revenues, despite his failures, are exactly what the owners want.  Anything is possible, but this seems like solid job security to me.

season starts fine only LA issue exists and only 1 of 3 owners of the whole will be unhappy very unhappy there  may be litigation over LA  by only 1 owner helps Goodell out of his control but players like hardy of Cowboys and Smith of Raiders playing without major blowback

The last two commissioners weathered storms just as potent as anything Goodell has encountered, and both survived for decades. The notion that Deflategate might do him in seems bizarre: If the issue hasn't crushed him so far, its power to do so should only weaken with time.

I believe he will. There have been quite a few "gates" and the like over the years, yet commissioners seem to last well. I would imagine this will be short term turbulence and there will likely be more scandals before one is large enough to lead to his ouster.
Given that he has remained commissioner through his handling of the various incidents in the past two years, it seems unlikely he will no longer be commissioner at the start of next season

Roger Goodell will still be at his position on opening day next year.  Not nearly as sure about 2017.  He has to pull out of a strong downward spiral caused by his handling of domestic violence and deflate gate.  I am not sure that he has the brains or judgment to do so.  If he handles TBI and other permanent injury issues as well as he has handled the issues of the past year, he might not make it to the end of 2016.
I'm increasing my forecast with the crowd.

He has stumbled in the past, but owners love him and the NFL continues to grow its profits.  Also, he benefited from deflategate in that (a) he took a strong stance on cheating, which is favored by a majority of owners, and (b) the scandal has had 0 impact on the Patriots, which pleases his erstwhile biggest supporter, Patriots owner Robert Kraft.

With a 39% approval rating among NFL players, 55% general public believing him untrustworthy about the Ray Rice video, being 0-4 in major decisions be overturned after challenged including Brady suspension, it may be likely that he will step down before the start of the 2016 season.

He'd have to assault his wife on camera while burning a US flag before they'd considered suspending, let alone dropping him. The 20 percent is for him being socially promoted to another lucrative opportunity.
The NFL is the most profitable sports league in the world and continues to grow under Roger Goodell. Profits are the only thing owners care about more than winning.
he has made (and will continue to make) too much revenue for the owners to be replaced at this time.

The owners (most of them) like him.

Goodell works for the owners, and he is making the owners more money than ever.
Owners are not motivated to remove him.

He is good at making money for the owners. Case closed.
he has done a good job overall

He makes the owners entirely too much money. There would need to be a huge scandal for the owners to fire him

Dateline 10-24-15 ... because of Deflategate, Goodell gets to restore his reputation as a tough guy and show that he is even-handed by cracking down on one of his former allies. Moreover, given that some people thought Goodell went easy on the Patriots during the 2007 Spygate incident, he now gets a do-over to prove just how tough he is.

Since 1946 the league has changed commissioners 9% of years.  This number has been trending down in recent decades with the 2 preceding commissioners having very long tenures.  On the other hand, Goodell is very unpopular with fans.  I don't think this matters much as long as the owners are happy with him.  The only reason I could see him getting pushed out is if public pressure from concussions grows and the owners use him as a scape goat.  Also, there is the chance he leaves on his own, which also seems unlikely.  I believe these factors balance each other out, with a slight leaning towards yes.
Despite upsetting one of his staunchest supporters in Bob Kraft, Goodell still has the support of the other powerful owners.  He has also presided over an unprecedented increase in NFL revenue.
Hedging a bit in case this fantasy gambling stuff blows up
although he should be "dethroned" their is just too much structure and history and power behind him.. booo
I do not see his removal before the Super Bowl

Goodell's current tenure of 10 years is far shorter than the mean tenure of his last two predecessors (17 and 29 years). While Goodell is a controversial figure to the public and NFL fans, the league is more successful than ever and is preparing to expand internationally in the next 5-10 years. Goodell is doing a good job at taking the heat for deflategate, domestic abuse scandals, and injury/concussion issues. He could be in danger in another few years, but he's completely safe for now. Also the status quo is in his favor.

While I believe Goodell and a majority of senior league officers make decisions based on personal politics rather than intellect and integrity,  NFL team owners bottom line investment returns seem more important than the perceptions of the general public and fans about whether Goodell is an effective commissioner and the league office is run well. NFL revenue expansion appear to be the measure of Goodell's yearly performance review rather than his player disciplinary miscues, court appeals,  and calculated media leaks.  Expansion or relocation efforts to host a team in Los Angeles can be expected to increase revenues.    It is not at all clear that playing US football in London where rugby and soccer have a long cultural tradition will be accepted and lead to a positive cash flow.  Goodell has publicly said several times "I am not a lawyer."  Tagliabue, Goodell's predecessor, was a lawyer.  Perhaps the job requires someone with a legal background that would help minimize the poor public relations issues we've seen from his handling player domestic violence and abuse issues.
